dialogues.text: Zissou and Eleanor’s bedroom. There is a little refrigera next to the bed. Mosquito netting hangs in front of the o terrace doors. Small birds fly all around the room. Eleanor sits in an old, pale blue, vinyl armchair smoking cigarette. One of the birds is perched on the armrest. Zi comes in the door. He takes off his red cap and throws it  55. across the room into a basket full of red caps. He takes Glock out of its holster, checks it, and sets it on top o the refrigerator. He walks quickly toward the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Had Ned’s heart stopped beating before you pulled him out of the water? Zissou stops. He looks guilty. He says quickly to himself

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: Had Ned’s heart stopped beating before we pulled him out of the water? (reluctantly) Yes -- but we got him going again pretty quick.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Don't go on this voyage right now, Steve. One of you’s already dead, after all.

dialogues.speaker: ZI1SSOU
dialogues.text: Who? (sadly) Oh, you mean Esteban. Yeah, thanks for bringing that up. Eleanor stares at Zissou. She nods once. She stands up an goes into the next room. Zissou listens as she dials the telephone and speaks off-screen:

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Zissou. Account number 9942. Is Tino available? No, immediately.

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: (loudly) Are you chartering a water-plane?

dialogues.speaker: EXT. COMPOUND. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Zissou follows Eleanor out the door of the house. She car three suitcases and wears a raincoat. Zissou holds a flashlight. They walk quickly through the gardens toward sea-plane waiting in the marina. Its engines are running. Zissou says forcefully:

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: Who's going to tell us the Latin names of all the fishes and everything? You know I can’t remember that shit! Please, stop, Eleanor. Please, stop! (stage-whispering loudly) There‘s a reporter from Oceanographic (more)  56. ZISSOU (cont'd) Explorer watching from the bunk-house. Don’t look at her. Eleanor stops. She looks back to the house. Jane is peeri out from her bedroom window. She ducks back inside. Elean sighs. Pause.

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: Why are you leaving?

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: I’m leaving because I don’t want to be a part of whatever’s going to happen out there.

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: Nobody knows what’s going to happen! And then we film it. That’s the whole concept. Eleanor starts walking again. Zissou follows her.

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: You knew when you married me I was an adventurer.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Don’t call yourself that. If somebody says it about you, OK. But --

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: Whatever I am, then. You knew it from the beginning. And, besides, I don’t think adventurer sounds that bad. Zissou tests this theory, saying to himself pleasantly:

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: Adventurer. They stop on the dock and lock at each other. Eleanor say over the sound of the plane:

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: I can’t believe you took that boy’s money.

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: (hesitates) He's an investor! (faintly) He's my sidekick.  57. Zissou touches Eleanor’s arm suddenly and points his flashlight at something on the ground. He says wistfully:

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: The sugar crabs are back. There are two very white, nearly translucent crabs tangle together scrambling around in circles on the beach. One h pink candy-stripes all over it, and the other has pale bl

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: They’re early this year. I’ve never seen them mating before the solstice.

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: (unsure) Is that mating? The male crab is now dead. The female crawls away carryin one of the dead male’s arms. Pause.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Good-bye, Steve.

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: (pained) Don’t say that. Even if it’s true, don’t say that. It’s too painful.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: What do you want me to say?

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: Say, Bon voyage. Long pause. Eleanor says sadly:

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR,
dialogues.text: Bon voyage. Eleanor gets into the sea-plane. The pilot guns the motor pulls away from the marina. Zissou stands alone at the en the dock as the sea-plane lifts-off the water, into the a Ned watches from his bedroom window. He turns out the lig

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The screen of a flat-bed editing console. A work-print is running. It has scratches and splices in it. The first im is a shot taken from the deck of the Belafonte of the ope sea with the Team Zissou flag in the foreground.  58.

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: Adventure No. 12: “The Jaguar Shark” (Part 2)

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: A close-up of Ned in his red cap and a pair of sunglasses smokes his pipe. The wind blows through his hair. Zissou in voice-over:

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Kingsley Ned Zissou, 29, Junior Grade Diving Tech, Executive Producer. Energetic, spirited, youthful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A chart of the ocean. A hand spins a compass and makes a with a pencil.

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Day three. En route to the Sea-Lab. INT. ZISSOU’S CABIN. DAY An extra-large stateroom with an office in it. Maps, awar and photographs of Zissou and various marine animals cove the walls. Zissou wears his brown suit with pin-stripes a thin black tie. He sits next to an overhead projector ona cart. He speaks calmly into the camera:

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: Normally, we would track the jaguar shark with the scanning monitor we keep on- board the Belafonte, but its power tubes have seized up and blown a gasket. An elevation-type drawing of a chrome undersea building labelled Operation Hennessey/Bernstein Sea-Laboratory app en a pull-down screen. The Belafonte is pictured on the w above the sea-lab. Ned stands beside the projected image. is dressed in a suit identical to Zissou’s. He motions to different parts of the drawing with a pointer.

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: We now proceed to the more advanced system located on a colleague’s off-shore facility. Zissou steps in front of the screen.  59.

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: This will be Team Zissou’s next stop. Zissou looks to Ned. Ned nods. There is a flash of white the film runs out.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Zissou, Ned, Renzo, and Vikram in the cutting room on the Belafonte. Each has a cup of coffee. Renzo rewinds the fi

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: See, this is what I’m talking about, Renzo. A relationship sub-plot. (to Ned) There‘s chemistry between us, you know? Ned smiles and nods. Zissou looks to Renzo for his respon Renzo shrugs. Zissou looks irritated.

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: Shouldn’t somebody be taking notes on what I'm saying? Let’s get this down on paper. Renzo sighs. He digs around on the bench for a pencil. Zi dictates:

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: Zissou and Ned sub-plot, Scene two, Ned assists Zissou with diagram and pointer.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. UPPER DECK. DAY
dialogues.text: Zissou and Jane sit at a table under a crane near the bac the ship. Jane’s tape recorder is in-between them. Zissou looks tense. Jane turns a page in her notebook.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Here’s a quote:

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: (frowns) Wait up. Who from?

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Zissou has an almost magical connection to the life of the sea. He speaks its language fluently. I’ve never met a boy like that in all my life. -- Lora Mandrake.  60. Zissou is moved as Jane reminds him of these remarks. He softly:

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: You should’ve opened with that one.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: He was your mentor. What was the --

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: Hey, intern! An intern with curly black hair carries a large, unwieldy iron pipe across the deck. He stops and looks to Zissou, struggling under the weight of the pipe.

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: Get me a Campari, will you?

dialogues.speaker: INTERN
dialogues.text: (hesitates) On the rocks? Zissou snaps his fingers and gives a thumbs up. The inter goes inside. Zissou looks to Jane and says cheerily:

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: You want to go up in my balloon?

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Pelé staring up at the sky as he operates a lever on the winch. Gears turn and grind. Klaus sprays some grease ont sprocket. Pelé looks to Klaus. He points into the air says:

dialogues.speaker: PELE
dialogues.text: I like her hair-do.

dialogues.speaker: KLAUS
dialogues.text: (shrugs) Me, too, but Steve already called her.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. BALLOON. DAY
dialogues.text: Zissou and Jane sit together in a basket hanging from a balloon fifty feet above the Belafonte. The balloon is pa blue, with a giant Team Zissou logo printed across it. A cable runs from the basket down to the ship below. Zissou holds a glass of Campari on ice. He says enthusiastically  Jane nods. 61.

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: I invented this for a network special on winds and currents. It's kind of a pain to inflate, but it’s great once you’re up here. She offers Zissou a stick of gum. He shakes his head. She puts one in her mouth. They look down past thei feet at the Belafonte below.

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: I'm sorry I made you cry the other day.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (pause) That’s OK. It’s not completely your fault, anyway. I’m going through some personal problems.

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: (interested) Really? What do you got?

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Well, I'm five months pregnant. My editor’s the father. He’s married -- but not to me.

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: Wow. That’s a rough ticket. (pause) You know, my first wife left me when I was your age. Zissou rolls-up his sleeve. A tattoo on his arm has Jacqueline, crossed-out, on top and Deep Search below it.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: What’s Deep Search?

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: My submarine. Zissou smiles. A Team Zissou flag attached to the ropes a the basket ripples in the breeze behind him. Jane smiles.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: I had this exact image of you tacked-up on the wall above my aquarium all through elementary school.  62.

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: (surprised) Oh, yeah? The official one, where I’m doing this? Zissou extends his arm and points to the horizon with a g determined look on his face. Jane looks suddenly transpor She says quietly:

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: That's the one.

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: Uh-huh. Well, maybe it’s just me, but I don’t feel like that person. I never did.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: (pause) To answer that question I’d have to tell you about my childhood, which I’m not going to do. Jane nods. She squints in the sun. Zissou holds up his ha and blocks the light from her eyes. They look at each oth for a minute. Zissou takes his hand away. The sun hits Ja eyes. Zissou kisses her on the lips. Jane pulls away slightly. Zissou reaches toward her face. Jane stops him her hand and stares at him, frozen.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Why’d you abandon Ned? ZISsSOU (pause) I didn’t. I never even met him. What kind of piece are you writing, cubbie?

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: {hesitates} It’s a three-part profile.

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: Yeah, but what’s your angle? Are you going to screw us on this deal? Silence. Jane says strangely:

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: I hope not.  63. Pause. Zissou shrugs. Jane spits out her gum over the sid into the ocean. She takes the glass of Campari out of Zissou’s hand and drinks it in one sip. She gives it back him. He frowns.

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: You really think it’s cool to hit the sauce when you got a bun in the oven? Jane looks at Zissou coldly. Zissou presses the red butto an intercom behind them and says:

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: Pelé, bring us back down, please. Zissou takes a joint out of his pocket. He reaches up abo pulls down on a chain, and lights the joint off the ballo hot air burner. He takes a puff.

dialogues.speaker: INT. LABORATORY. DAY
dialogues.text: Zissou and Anne-Marie sit with Wolodarsky at a console. Wolodarsky is composing a piece of music on his keyboard. Anne-Marie is topless. Two monitors display moving underw point-of-view shots. They are labelled Dolphin 1 and Dolp 2. Zissou pours himself a fresh glass of Campari on ice.

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: I don’t have a problem with objective reporting. What I have a problem with is some wombat coming on my boat and trying to railroad me, you know? Wolodarsky does not respond. He keeps playing his music. Zissou sighs.

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: See if you can get one of the dolphins to swim under the hull and give us a look. Wolodarsky stops playing his music and types a Morse Code style message into a computer. He waits for an answer. He types it again. He turns to Zissou.

dialogues.speaker: WOLODARSKY
dialogues.text: Either they can’t hear us, or they don’t understand.

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: (shakes his head) Son of a bitch. I’m sick of these dolphins! (to Anne-Marie) (more)  64. ZISSOU (cont'd) Run a cost breakdown of what we're spending on them, and give me a report.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. BELAFONTE. NIGHT
dialogues.text: A porthole to the library. Jane sits at a desk writing intently in her note book. She unwraps a stick of gum and starts chewing it.

dialogues.speaker: BOOM TO
dialogues.text: Klaus, Wolodarsky, and Ogata on the main deck, one level They lean against the railing, drinking red, orange, and yellow frozen cocktails. Klaus takes a little paper umbre out of his drink and opens it.

dialogues.speaker: DOLLY TO
dialogues.text: The window of the bridge. Pelé sits inside, at the wheel, strumming his guitar. He makes an adjustment on the instrument panel.

dialogues.speaker: BOOM TO
dialogues.text: The top of the look-out tower. Zissou stands alone above ship smoking a joint in the moonlight. Ned comes out and joins him. He lights his pipe. An oil tanker goes by slow in the distance. Thunder rumbles. Zissou says mysteriousl

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: Quiet out there tonight. Can you hear the jack-whales singing? Ned listens. A foghorn blows long and low. He whispers:

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: It’s beautiful. What do you think they’re saying?

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: (hesitates) Well, that was the sludge tanker over there, but -- A mournful whale cry now sounds in the distance. Zissou h up his finger.

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: There you go. That’s them. Ned smiles and nods.  65.

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: By the way, would you mind if I made some modifications to the Team Zissou insignia? I had a few ideas that might --

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: You mean the patch?

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: The insignia.

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: Yeah, it’s probably kind of dated, isn’t it? Sure, take a crack at it. Make it a little trendier.

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: (pleased) All right. Zissou pats Ned on the back. He smiles.

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: I really enjoy being around you, Ned. (looking down over the railing) He’s got a very nice way about him. Don’t you think, Klaus? Klaus’ voice answers from off-screen, below:

dialogues.speaker: KLAUS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: How should I know? I'm not his estranged father. Zissou nods. He says to Ned sincerely:

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: Are you finding what you were looking for? Out here with me? I hope so. Ned hesitates. He says suddenly:

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: I wrote you a letter about seventeen years ago.

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: {pause) You mean like a fan letter? Ned nods. A strange look crosses Zissou’s face. He hesita  66.

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: Did I write you back? I try to answer as Many personally as I can. Ned reaches into his pocket and takes out an old, beaten envelope. He hands it to Zissou. Zissou opens it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A worn and faded typewritten note on Team Zissou statione Zissou reads it in voice-over. Dear Ned Plimpton, First, in answer to your question: always. Second, thank you very much for naming your bug after me. My wife tells me it is actually a type of gnat. You strike me as a very special boy and a key member of the Zissou Society. I wis I could come visit you in Kentucky and assist you with yo work. I remember your mother. Take care of yourself, Ned Plimpton. You’ve served well. Your friend, Capt. Steve Zissou Dictated but not read. (S8Z/jz)

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Zissou with tears in his eyes. He nods and says to Ned:

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: Yeah. More or less standard boilerplate, I guess.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. SEA-LABORATORY. DAY
dialogues.text: A large, chrome cylinder with a pod at the top sticks twe five feet out of the ocean. Operation Hennessey is writte across the side, with Bernstein Labs Ltd. below it. There portholes and a platform with a railing around the pod, a ladder runs down the cylinder into the water. A Zodiak motorboat is tied to the bottom of the ladder, and the Belafonte sits at anchor fifty feet away. Zissou, Ned, and Jane stand on the platform waiting in th rain. An intern holds an umbrella over Zissou. Zissou has his swimsuit. Everyone else wears Team Zissou slickers. The door of the sea-laboratory has a thick steel chain la through the handle with a padlock on it.

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: There’s some real high-tech gear inside this deal, believe me. First, we’ll go downstairs and turn on the tracking (more)  67. ZISSOU (cont 'd) system, and as long as the batteries on that homing dart haven’t gone dead, we‘1l get --

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: Who locked us out?

dialogues.speaker: ANNE-MARIE
dialogues.text: (bitterly) No one. We're trespassing.

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: (hesitates) Steve, are we allowed to go in there?

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: (pause) It's the scientific community, man.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: I’m required by law to notify the bank of any illegal activities.

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: (annoyed) Just do what you got to do to cover your ass, Bill. Klaus comes up the ladder onto the platform. He carries a large crowbar.

dialogues.speaker: KLAUS
dialogues.text: I got it.

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: Good. Here. Klaus hands Zissou the crowbar. Zissou cracks open the padlock. He pulis the chain off the door handle. He takes key out of his pocket, unlocks the door, and opens it. A burglar alarm goes off.

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: Fuck! They wired it. Klaus, go back and get me cable snippers.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: A life-sized cross-section of the lowest level of the sea laboratory at the ocean's floor. This is a highly sophisticated laboratory filled with computers, aquariums microscopes, and cameras. Large windows look out into the ocean. Stilts reach from the bottom of the structure ten down into the sand. A manta ray swims by outside.  68. Zissou, Ned, Pelé, and Bill sit at a radar monitor. A sma green blip pulses on the screen and beeps. Vikram stands the corner with a 16mm camera on his shoulder. An intern wearing headphones operates the boom. Three other interns wait beside him. Zissou takes a deep breath and says quietly to himself:

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: OK. Action. (performing) Well, look who’s back in town. You‘ve travelled 150 miles since we last heard from you. This son of a bitch is headed for the South Pacific. Jane and Anne-Marie come down the stairs into the laborat Zissou points to Jane and says intensely:

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: Turn on your tape recorder, cubbie! Jane looks at the radar screen. She turns to Zissou.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Is it the jaguar shark? ZISsou On the record? Yes. (to Vikram) Cut it. Vikram cuts the camera. Jane looks confused.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Was I just in the movie?

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: Yeah. You need to sign a release.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: But you’ve actually located the shark?

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: (excited) You bet your fucking ass, we did! Zissou stands up and puts out his hand to Jane for her to give him five. Jane hesitates. She slaps Zissou’s hand. Zissou says to his crew:  69.

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: All right. We've got twenty-five to thirty minutes before the Coast Guard gets here to arrest us. I want you to load all Hennessey’s best gear onto the Belafonte in fifteen.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: (in disbelief) You're going to steal his stuff?

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: (hesitates) No, we’ll get it back to him. Interns, let’s see some hustle. The interns start unplugging equipment and putting things boxes. Operation Hennessey is stencilled on everything. A Marie looks at a chart next to the radar monitor. She fro Zissou walks out through a hatch and closes it behind him Anne-Marie picks up the chart.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: What’s this, Pelé? Pelé looks uneasy. He shrugs. Anne-Marie goes out the hat after Zissou. He is on his way up a ladder. She follows h

dialogues.speaker: ANNE-MARIE
dialogues.text: Steve?

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: Uh-huh? Zissou and Anne-Marie enter the upper level of the underw section of the structure, which is the living quarters. T is a kitchen, a bathroom, a dining room, and two cabins w sets of bunks and exercise equipment.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE-MARIE
dialogues.text: Do you know you’ve just charted us on a course through unprotected waters? Anne-Marie shows Zissou the chart. Zissou says agreeably:

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: Yeah, we’re going to take the short cut.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE-MARIE
dialogues.text: (concerned) But it’s outside I.M.U. jurisdication. There isn’t any --  70.

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: I know, baby, but look at the map. If we go your way, it’s about -- Zissou glances at the chart and holds up his fingers to indicate:

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: -- four inches. If we go mine, it’s an inch and a half. You want to pay for the extra gas? They walk past Klaus and Wolodarsky in the dining room. K watches Wolodarsky work on a piece of equipment on the ta He says casually:

dialogues.speaker: KLAUS
dialogues.text: What kind of system is this?

dialogues.speaker: WOLODARSKY
dialogues.text: They just upgraded to the Bernstein Nines last summer.

dialogues.speaker: KLAUS
dialogues.text: (surprised) The Nines are out already? Wolodarsky nods. Zissou sees an espresso machine on the kitchen counter. He examines it.

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: Does this do cappuccino? Zissou picks up the espresso machine and carries it away. Anne-Marie follows him through another hatch, and they st climbing a spiral staircase that winds upwards. A school fish swims by outside.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE-MARIE
dialogues.text: Wait a second, Steve. This isn’t the procedure. There is a loud crashing sound from below. Zissou stops a looks down the stairwell. Wolodarsky yells up to him:

dialogues.speaker: WOLODARSKY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Steve, one of the interns just fell down the stairs with the main tracking processor.

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: Well, make sure we steal the back-up.  71. Zissou and Anne-Marie approach the top of the staircase. Outside the cylinder is the water’s surface.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE -MARIE
dialogues.text: Are you listening to me? Eleanor told me --

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: Shut up before you jinx us, Anne-Marie. Anne-Marie stops. She looks furious. She turns and walks down the staircase. Zissou goes up, out the door, onto th platform at the top of the structure. Ogata is fishing from the railing in the rain.

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: You catching anything? Ogata shakes his head. Zissou hands the espresso machine the intern with the curly hair.

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: Hook this up and make me a latte. The intern nods. Zissou opens an umbrella. He takes out a joint and lights it. He checks his watch. The interns sta coming out with crates and boxes. They set them on the platform and go back inside for more. Ned appears in the doorway. He stands next to Zissou. Zissou sighs.

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: You know, cubbie’s kind of a sucker- maker, but she’s got some moves.

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: I agree.

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: If she wasn’t a bull-dyke, I think I might have a little bit of a thing for her. Ned turns to Zissou blankly.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. OCEAN. DUSK
dialogues.text: The Belafonte runs at full speed on an open sea under gre skies.  72.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CARGO HOLD. NIGHT
dialogues.text: A storage room at the bottom of the ship. Folding chairs been set up among the suitcases, crates, and boxes. The exercise equipment and espresso machine from Hennessey’s laboratory are also there. Zissou and Wolodarsky sit at a radar monitor connected to large jumble of electronic gadgets stacked precariously o top of one another and fastened together with rubber band and duct tape. There are cords and wires all over the roo Ned, Jane, Klaus, Ogata, Anne-Marie, and Bill watch inten They have flashlights and candles. Wolodarsky points to a large blip near the edge of the screen.

dialogues.speaker: WOLODARSKY
dialogues.text: If the creature continues on its current migratory route, our paths should converge in less than four days.

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: (instantly) I want to get there in three. Ogata, check the --

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: Vladimir, what is this blip over here? Ned points to a smaller, fainter blip near the center of screen.

dialogues.speaker: WOLODARSKY
dialogues.text: I don’t know. I’ve been trying to figure that out. We might have both of them mixed up, or it could be the other way around. Anyway, we'll be right on top of it first thing in the morning. Jane looks to Ned, impressed. Zissou says grudgingly:

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: Good eye, Ned.

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: Thank you. Should we investigate it? Everyone turns to Zissou. He looks slightly irritated.

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: Yeah. We’1l do a quick dive at six AM and scope out this phantom signal -- it’s probably just one of Hennessey’s research (more)  73. ZISSou (cont 'd) turtles -- but I want to be back on the road by lunch.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Zissou pulling Ned aside as the rest of the group walks o of the cargo hold and starts up the stairs. Renzo stays behind listening to Wolodarsky play a composition on his keyboard. Zissou says to Ned confidentially:

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: Do me favor, will you? Next time you get a hot idea in front of the reporter, whisper it in my ear, first. Otherwise, I lock like kind of a daydream-johnny, you know?

dialogues.speaker: INT. SPA. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Ned floats in the jacuzzi. Jane sits on the edge across f him with her feet in the water. They both have on Team Zi swimsuits, and Ned wears a pair of diving goggles. The ai filled with steam. Jane says in disbelief:

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: You let him change your name?

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: Well, we changed it together.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: What was it before?

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: I left Kentucky as Edward Plimpton.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (indignant) That's a million times better. Change it back, Ned. I really don’t see you as a Kingsley Zissou.

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: (sighs) Yeah, probably, me, neither. Anyway, I don’t know if I even belong here. Do you think Steve and I have a family resemblance? Jane reaches out to Ned and lifts his goggles off his fac onto the top of his head. She looks at him for a minute.

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: I guess it doesn’t really matter, anyway.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (pause) Why the £ are you paying for this movie out of your own pocket?

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: (hesitates) Well, I think it’s a good investment. Or, besides, I don’t have anything better to do with my money, anyway. I’m alone now. Ned puts his goggles back on and sinks lower into the wat Jane watches him curiously.

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: I admire the man. He inspires people.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: That may very well be true, but he’s also --

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: (gently) So what, Jane? Jane hesitates. Ned says sincerely:

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: He’s not taking advantage of me.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: {pause) OK. Ned and Jane stare at each other in silence. The condensa on Ned’s goggles fogs them over completely.

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: I feel bad for you and that baby.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (pause) Don’t feel bad for us. Silence. Ned shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: Here.  75. Ned holds out Jane’s miniature, sparkling sand-dollar. It hangs on a pink thread.

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: I stole it back and strung it on some peppermint dental floss in case you want to wear it like a necklace. Jane puts the string around her neck. She looks at Ned an smiles. She moves along the edge, closer to him. She kiss him on the lips. Ned says quietly:

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: I’ve only had two girlfriends in my life. That I’ve gone to bed with, I mean. Jane looks surprised, then dazed.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Wow. That makes me want to cry. The door bursts open. Ogata and Pelé rush into the room a jump into the jacuzzi. Pelé leans back and puts on a slee mask. Ogata tears the wax paper wrapping off a ham sandwi and takes a bite. INT. JANE’S CABIN. NIGHT Jane’s clothes, papers, and junk-food wrappers are strewn over the room. Zissou stands at the desk reading one of Jane's notebooks. He has a crowbar in his hand. He turns page. Jane appears in the doorway with a towel wrapped ar her. Her hair is wet. She hesitates. She says loudly:

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Woah! Zissou looks to Jane and holds up the notebook.

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: Are you happy with the piece, Jane?

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (shocked) What are you --

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: Am I? No.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Put that down!  76.

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: I assume I’m Mr. Z. I’m sorry you think my hat is -- what was the word? (checking Jane’s notes) Contrived. And that: Zissou flips to another page. He reads at random:

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: The Zissou of my childhood represents -- (frowning) -- every dream I’ve come to regret? What? Why? Jane crosses over to Zissou and grabs her notebook out of hand. She says bitterly:

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: I’m going to have to start locking my f-ing door.

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: It was locked. I kicked it in. (irritated) Why don’t you just curse?

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (pause) Because I’m trying to get out of the habit before I have my fucking baby.

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: (realizing) Oh. That makes sense. Well, clean this room up, anyway. It looks like it was hit by a goddamn typhoon.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Get out. Zissou sighs. He takes off his hat and looks at it.

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: Please, don’t make fun of me. I just wanted to flirt with you. Jane hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: I'll get an intern to fix the door. Zissou turns away and walks out.  77.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A high-speed message transmission module as it laser-prin the following words onto a pink form: FROM: I.M.U. Headquarters TO: Operation Hennessey ATTN: Carl

dialogues.speaker: INT. RADIO ROOM. NIGHT
dialogues.text: A pristine cabin filled with ultra-modern satellite telecommunications equipment. Three large portholes look to the ocean outside. The moon sits low on the horizon. A young, blond Englishman in a white Operation Hennessey uniform tears the pink document out of the printer.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: A long corridor with illuminated floors and glowing white walls. The ship’s turbines hum from below. The young Englishman walks briskly down the hallway carrying the pi document .

dialogues.speaker: EXT. REAR DECK. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Hennessey sits on a chaise lounge at the back of his ship His hair is wet, and he wears only a white Operation Hennessey swimsuit and a towel around his neck. A young, blond Englishman dressed only in an Operation Hennessey swimsuit sits on a stool beside him. The first Englishman arrives with the pink document and h it to Hennessey. Hennessey reads it and frowns.

dialogues.speaker: HENNESSEY
dialogues.text: This is a message from the I.M.U. Coast Guard. Apparently, some crooked fuckers broke into my sea-lab yesterday.

dialogues.speaker: SWIMSUIT ENGLISHMAN
dialogues.text: How awful. Did they nick anything?

dialogues.speaker: HENNESSEY
dialogues.text: It doesn't say. They probably just trashed the place. {gritting his teeth) I’m so pissed I want to spit. Hennessey crumples the document in his fist. He spits on deck. He uncrumples the document and looks at it again. H says to the first Englishman:  78.

dialogues.speaker: HENNESSEY
dialogues.text: Hugo, tell Carl to load my elephant gun with buckshot. We’re going to hunt down these sickos.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. MAIN DECK. DAY
dialogues.text: The next morning, onboard the Belafonte. Pelé assists Zis Ned, Klaus, and Ogata as they put on their wet suits and check their equipment. They carry nets and shovels and ba of gear. Zissou has a spear-gun. Jane, Anne-Marie, and th interns stand gathered around watching and helping. Vikra films the scene. Zissou plugs a cord into a socket on the side of his helm and adjusts an antenna on the top of his head. He says to Jane:

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: Supposedly, Cousteau and his cronies invented the idea of putting walkie- talkies into the helmet, but we made ours with a special rabbit ear on top so you can pipe in some music. The group of divers jumps into the water.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. OCEAN. DAY
dialogues.text: An undersea forest. Large tree-like plants reach thirty f up from the ocean's floor. They sway and quiver in the eurrent. Schools of fish dart among the trunks. A web-foo water lizard swims past Zissou, Ned, Klaus, Ogata, and Vikram. They turn on flashlights as they enter the thicket. Vikra films the others as they make their way through the tangl branches, into a small clearing. A partially demolished charter jet lies half-buried in th sand. It is covered with barnacles, and fish swim in and of the windows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A black-box recording console stuck in the wreckage. It b quietly, and a red light blinks next to an antenna on its casing. A blowfish swims over to it and puffs up like a balloon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zissou as he turns to Vikram and says over a radio head-s built into his diving mask:

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: Let's start with the reverse. Vikram nods and moves beyond Zissou, to a second position Zissou motions for Ned, Klaus, and Ogata to follow him ba into the trees. Ned says to Zissou over his radio head-se

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: Would it be possible for me to address you as Dad in this scene?

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: (instantly) No. Why? Ned hesitates. He looks embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: Oh. Excuse me. I’m sorry. I forgot you --

dialogues.speaker: KLAUS
dialogues.text: (bewildered) Where you coming from, jack-off? Shit!

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: (to himself) It’s not a bad impulse, though. Some kind of nick-name. Not that one -- it’s too specific -- but try to think of something else.

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: (hesitates) Another name?

dialogues.speaker: OGATA
dialogues.text: How about Steevsy?

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: That’s good. Try it. What were you going to say before? Silence. Ned says simply:

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: Good luck, Steevsy.

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: Fantastic. Let’s go.  80. Zissou leads the other three, swimming into the clearing again. They approach Vikram. They stare in amazement at t wreckage while Vikram films them in close-up. Zissou sign for Vikram to cut. The five divers enter the crashed plane. A bright red oct jets out of a hole in the fuselage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zissou sits in the sound booth talking into a microphone. wears headphones. Renzo and Vikram watch him through the glass. Zissou finishes performing his narration:

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: We examine the crash-site, but are careful not to disturb the forensic evidence. (to Renzo) How was that?

dialogues.speaker: RENZO
dialogues.text: Not bad. The first take was a little faster. Here’s the footage of Ned saving your life.

dialogues.speaker: 4ISSOU
dialogues.text: (frowns) I told you not to print that, Vikram. He didn’t save my life. That’s not the way I want this sub-plot to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The screen of the flat-bed editing console. A slate says 3, Take 1, Mysterious Jet Sequence. Inside the plane. Zissou’s leg is pinned under an exposed turbine sticking through the side of the fuselage. A ther with barnacles all over it falls from the luggage rack an clunks him on the head. He looks up and sees a large meta trunk shifting precariously above him. He reaches up and his hand against it to stop it from falling on him. A miniature sea-scorpion circles near his neck. He tugs at leg violently with a look of panic on his face under his diving mask. Ned swims over and kneels down beside Zissou. He pulls an twists on part of a crushed seat-back pressed against Zissou’s ankle. An arm-rest breaks off, and Zissou’s leg freed. Zissou and Ned dedge away as the trunk crashes dow and the sea-scorpion darts away.  81. Zissou swims directly into the camera and puts his hand o the lens.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Zissou focussed on the image on the screen. He shakes his head and says, annoyed: ZISsoUu That’s incoherent. I wouldn’t know how to use this bit.

dialogues.speaker: INT. HALLWAY. DAY
dialogues.text: Ned comes down the stairs and sees Klaus at the end of th corridor. He pauses.

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: Could I have a moment with you, Klaus? Klaus looks to Ned. He frowns. Ned walks down the hallway stops in front of Klaus. They stare at each other.

dialogues.speaker: KLAUS
dialogues.text: What? Ned slaps Klaus in the face. Klaus looks taken aback.

dialogues.speaker: KLAUS
dialogues.text: Why’d you do that?

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: Because I owed you one.

dialogues.speaker: KLAUS
dialogues.text: (upset) But you gave me a warning already. You stood up for yourself.

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: I still owed you one.

dialogues.speaker: KLAUS
dialogues.text: Well, now I owe you one.

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: No. Now we're even, Klaus looks confused. He sounds highly emotional.

dialogues.speaker: KLAUS
dialogues.text: Why’re you doing this to me? He’s not my father, you know? I don’t have that.  82.

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: (hesitates) What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: KLAUS
dialogues.text: We’re even, dammit! That’s it!

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: The ocean under a heavy mist. An old, ramshackle speedboa darts past the Belafonte, circles back, and races away. Zissou watches from the look-out tower. He frowns.

dialogues.speaker: INT. BRIDGE. DAY
dialogues.text: Zissou flips through a book called Trawlers, Junks, and Dinghies: A Vessel Identification Manual by Eleanor Zisso Pelé is at the wheel. Klaus sits glumly beside him.

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: No, it was like a beat-up little jalopy. I don’t know what you’d call it. You didn’t see it?

dialogues.speaker: PELE
dialogues.text: (staring straight ahead) I didn’t see it, boss.

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: (irritated) Well, keep your eyes peeled. Zissou looks through the windshield into the fog with a p of boy scout binoculars. He lowers them.

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: Klaus, check who’s on watch. I’1ll be in the sauna. Zissou walks out of the bridge. Klaus looks at a clipboar hanging on the wall.

dialogues.speaker: KLAUS
dialogues.text: Pelé and -- (frowns) -- who the shit is Kingsley Zissou? INT. NED’S CABIN. DAY Jane sits on the edge of Ned’s bunk. She wears a tight sleeveless T-shirt. Ned has on a Team Zissou swimsuit. He leaning into Jane’s lap with his ear pressed against her stomach. He feels the baby kick. He looks startled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that him?

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Uh-huh. That’s him.

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: I've never felt a baby in someone's stomach before. Ned sits up. He seems very moved.

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: I think you’1l make a very good single mother. Jane smiles sadly. She spits out her gum into her hand. drops it into a glass of water. She says softly:

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: Although it puts you both at a tremendous disadvantage. 83. She Pause. Ned and Jane start to make-out passionately with t hands all over each other. Jane pulls-off Ned’s shirt. Ne suddenly locks concerned.

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: You know, Steve has a little bit of a thing for you.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (surprised) Why do you say that?

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: Because he told me.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (intrigued) Really? I thought he hated my guts.

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: Well, I think you hurt his feelings, but that doesn’t mean --

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: He says I hurt his feelings? Jane shakes her head. She says philosophically:  84.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: That’s so f-ed up.

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: He called you a sucker-maker.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (hesitates) What’s a sucker-maker? Ned considers this. He shrugs. One of the albino dolphin scouts stares in through a porthole.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CORRIDOR. DAY
dialogues.text: Zissou walks past the doorway to the laboratory dressed i his bathrobe with a towel around his neck and a bottle of Pellegrino in his hand. A rolled-up plastic sandwich bagg filled with pot sticks out of his pocket. He stops. He co back. He looks into the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The screen of one of the dolphin camera monitors. There i glimpse of Jane touching Ned’s cheek in the porthole befo the image darts away into the water.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Zissou. He hesitates. He walks away.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. STERN. DAY
dialogues.text: Pelé sits at the back of the ship playing a David Bowie s on his guitar. He does not notice the speedboat approachi again through the mist behind the ship. As it nears the Belafonte, it becomes apparent that its passengers are fourteen Indonesian men with machetes and machine-guns. O of them raises a bamboo ladder into the air.

dialogues.speaker: INT. SPA. DAY
dialogues.text: Zissou sits alone in the sauna smoking a joint with his e closed. He is dressed in a swimsuit. He has an ashtray balanced on his knee. The air is filled with steam. There is a loud cracking sound from the decks above, foll by a low rumble. Zissou frowns. He opens his eyes. There sudden rush of footsteps flooding down the stairs. Someon pounds on the door. Zissou hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: 4ISSOU
dialogues.text: Yeah?  85.

dialogues.speaker: KLAUS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Steve, would you mind opening the door? Silence. Zissou takes one last puff on the joint, puts it out, and sets the ashtray aside. He stands up and goes to door. He rubs the condensation off the porthole. Klaus’ face is revealed with the end of a machine-gun stu into his temple, a machete held against his neck, and a f gripping a handful of his hair. INT. NED’S CABIN. DAY Ned and Jane lie on the bed together. There is a knock on door. They look at each other. Jane frowns.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Uh-huh?

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (confused) Jane? Is Ned in there?

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: Hi, Steevsy.

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (pause) Uh, hi. What’s going on?

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: (shrugs) Just doing a little book-reading. There is some sudden shoving and yelling in Indonesian in hallway.

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I guess you better let us in. Ned gets up and looks under the door. He sees Zissou’s po blue slippers and the dirty feet of seven men in worn-out boots, tattered sandals, and sneakers with duct-tape hold them together -- plus the tip of a machete. He is stunned

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: What’s happening? Is that -- Are those hi- jackers?

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Well, we call them pirates out here, Ned. You’re supposed to be on watch, by the way.  86. Ned checks his watch. He looks horrified.

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: Oh, my God. You're right. Ned opens the door. The pirates instantly burst into the room. They have scars on their faces and wild looks in th eyes. They chaotically manhandle Zissou, Ned, and Jane, screaming and swinging machetes. cur TO: Zissou, Ned, and Jane on the floor tied-up with ropes and twine. The door is closed, and they are alone in the room

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: You know, if we had a little warning, we could've fought these guys off.

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: (upset) I'm sorry, Steve.

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: This is why we're supposed to have our Glocks on us at all times. (yells at the ceiling) Even the interns, Anne-Marie! (calmly) So tell me again -- you’re reading to each other in French?

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: No, it’s in English. It was translated.

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: Well, you know, you’re not supposed to go into each other’s cabins on a boat.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: It’s just kind of an unwritten maritime rule when you're at sea. Especially for the goddamn look-out. (screaming at Ned) I’m furious at you!

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: (shaken) I’m so sorry.  87.

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: Me, too, pal. You hung us out to dry. You know, if we don’t handle this right, we're going to all get murdered, including her unborn British child. Jane bursts into tears. Ned looks devastated. The door op A pirate wearing a kamikaze headband comes in, goes over Ned, and pounds him in the head with the butt of his mach Ned falls over, knocked-out cold. Zissou kicks and thrashes around but is bound fast to a p on the wall. The pirate drags Ned out the door. Zissou ye after him desperately:

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: I’m going to kill you for that, you asshole! I’m going to hit you so fucking hard you won’t -- The pirate closes the door.

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: Please, don’t hurt him!

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Zissou and Jane coming up the stairs together with their hands tied behind their backs. One of the pirates follows them with a machine-gun.

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: Watch me. I’11 let you know when I’m ready to make a move.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (urgently) Steve, it’s way safer for us to just do what they say. They probably only want our money and jewels and shit.

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: Uh-huh, well, how am I supposed to finish my movie, then? Zissou, Jane, and the pirate walk out onto the deck. A do with only three legs runs wildly over to them, snarling. entire crew is lined-up facing a wall, down on their knee blindfolded, with their arms bound. Zissou looks shocked.

dialogues.speaker: Z1SSOU
dialogues.text: Fuck! Jesus! Holy fuck!  88.

dialogues.speaker: KLAUS
dialogues.text: They're going to kill us, Steve! Zissou looks to Klaus. Klaus is sobbing. Zissou yells to

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: I’m patting you on the back right now, Klausie! Don’t be scared! I’m going to get us through this, everybody! Ogata? Como esta, pal? Zissou looks over the side of the ship. The pirates are loading cans of fuel into their speedboat. A skinny, thir year-old Indonesian boy huddles terrified at the rudder. lies unconscious, tied-up on the floor, partially stuffed into a potato sack. There is blood all over the side of h face. Zissou looks as if he is about to cry. He yells strangely:

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: Wake up, Ned-o! I’m sorry I yelled at you! (to the pirates) I need to speak to the man in charge, fellas! The pirate with the kamikaze headband holds a Glock to th back of an intern’s head and shouts at him hysterically.

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: Don’t point that at him. He’s an unpaid intern. Zissou slowly moves his bound hands in front of the gun o the back of the intern’s head. He notices Vikram has one the cameras in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: What kind of coverage you getting, Vikram?

dialogues.speaker: VIKRAM
dialogues.text: I just kept it rolling until they put this hood over my head. Bill and one of the pirates start an animated discussion Indonesian. The pirate shouts something to his colleagues Zissou says to himself:

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: Bill speaks their language. (yelling) What’s he saying, Billy?  89.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Apparently, they’re going to take a hostage, and they’ve chosen Ned, but -- Bill holds up a finger and listens as the pirates negotia with one another. He nods.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Yes. Now that they’ve learned I speak Indonesian, they seem to have changed their minds. Five of the pirates surround Bill. One of them takes out buck-knife. An older pirate comes out of the bridge. He w a baseball cap. He and the other pirates talk rapidly wit one another.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Do we have a vault? He wants to know about the vault.

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: (blankly) There’s no vault.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: He says, Give us the currency? I believe that's the word. He appears to have seen one of your films.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: A small, jerry-rigged television set behind a cheap restaurant kitchen in the slums of Jakarta. The pirates w a fifteen-year-old episode of The Life Aquatic. Some of t appear to be cooks or waiters. In the program, Zissou and Klaus sit beside Esteban as he opens a yellow safe on-boa the ship. He shows the camera bills and coins from variou countries. Zissou explains in voice-over:

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Our vault contains at least ten different currencies from all over the world at any given moment, and we are prepared for every kind of financial necessity. The pirates look intrigued.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Zissou staring at Bill.  30.

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: Tell him times have changed. Four pirates come out onto the deck carrying the yellow s Zissou sighs.

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: There goes Ned’s inheritance.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Should I try to negotiate with them?

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: {pause) Yeah. Try that. Tell them to get off my boat right now, or there's going to be a major shit-storm. Bill calmly addresses the pirates in Indonesian. Zissou interrupts:

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: Did you say shit-storm?

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: (hesitates) Well, I’m trying to be more --

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: (sharply) Translate what I’m saying, Bill. Pause. Bill nods. He translates more aggressively to the pirates. The largest of the pirates punches Bill in the stomach. Bill doubles over onto the deck. Zissou looks surprised.

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: Woah! Woah! Woah! Step it down a notch! Bill lies moaning on the deck. The large pirate picks him and heaves him over the side of the ship into a net. He i lowered from a pulley to the speedboat with a crate of bananas. Ned is hoisted back up and thrown on the deck. Zissou calls out to him:

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: Ned-o? Can you hear me? Ned does not respond. Zissou and Jane are forced down ont their knees and blindfolded. Zissou yells desperately:  91.

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: We'll get you back, Billy! Is everybody else safe? Anne-Marie! You OK, honey? Anne-Marie sounds miserable. Her voice cracks:

dialogues.speaker: ANNE-MARIE
dialogues.text: No, I’m not. I told you these were unprotected waters. Zissou shakes his head and all the energy seems to drain his body. He says to himself in a pained voice:

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: What a fucking nightmare. Dark clouds roll in above the ship. Zissou turns to Jane says suddenly:

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: Be cool on this shit, OK, cubbie? I mean, at least try to show both sides.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (quietly) I need to find a baby for this father.

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: (pause) Yeah. I think I know what you mean. Zissou nods. He wriggles his arms, testing the knots. Thu rumbles in the distance. Zissou takes a deep breath. He s calmly to himself in a loud, clear voice:

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: OK. This is it, Zissou. Here we go. Klaus turns toward Zissou. He hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: KLAUS
dialogues.text: Steve? What are you --

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: (yelling) I said get your ass the hell off of my boat ! Zissou jumps up and whips off his blindfold. He throws a lever on a valve, and steam shoots out of a pipe. He punc one of the pirates in the face. He grabs the pirate’s pis throws him overboard, and starts shooting. Bullets ricoch A hose snaps open, and water bursts out. An electrical fu  92. box breaks apart, showering sparks. The pirate with the kamikaze headband holds a machete over the intern with th curly black hair. Zissou shoots the pirate in the neck. T pirate clutches at his throat, moaning, but manages to ch into the intern’s shoulder. Eight of the pirates are already in their speedboat. The remaining four burst into frenzied screaming and shooting They beat and kick at Zissou's crew. One of them throws a hand grenade. Zissou hollers:

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: Grenade! Everyone dives for cover. There is an explosion near the of the ship. The pirates scramble over the railings, jump into their speedboat, and race away. Zissou stands at the prow of the Belafonte and empties his pistol at the speedboat. He throws the gun after them. Pause. He says t himself:

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: I’ve never seen a bond company stooge stick his neck out like that. Zissou shakes his head. The pirate with the kamikaze head lies face down on the deck in a pool of blood. Zissou sta over him and says defiantly:

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: I know this asshole. I told him I was going to kill him. Zissou turns to his passengers and crew. They are all loo at him with their blindfolds on. The ship is in flames be them. An electrical storm crackles on the horizon. Strang lightning bolts shoot upwards. Pelé tilts his head curiou with tears running down his cheeks from under his blindfo

dialogues.speaker: PELE
dialogues.text: What’s that sound? Is that --

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: The Arctic Night-lights, yeah. (quoting) As if the natural world’s been turned upside-down. -- Lord Mandrake. (unquote) Vikram, get some cut-aways of this miracle. Klaus, Ogata, put out the deck- fires before we sink. The three-legged dog goes over to Zissou and growls at hi  93.

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: Those fucking amateurs. You left your dog, you idiots!

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: The look-out tower. Zissou stands with Klaus and Ogata ab the blackened, smoldering ship. Pelé sprays a fire extinguisher on the bridge, below. Everyone on deck looks shell-shocked. Zissou shakes his head and says sadly:

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: Wrap the stiff in a tablecloth. We’re going to bury him at sea.

dialogues.speaker: OGATA
dialogues.text: (hesitates) Shouldn't we give him to the authorities or something?

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: (pause) No.

dialogues.speaker: KLAUS
dialogues.text: I’1l write up a few words to read over him. Zissou nods. One of the interns comes out onto the tower, shivering. His arm is in a bloody sling. Zissou says gent

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: How you holding up there, intern? You doing OK? The intern nods. Zissou sighs. He pats the intern on the back.

dialogues.speaker: INT. DINING ROOM. NIGHT
dialogues.text: A lobster dinner for the crew. There is a half-empty jero of champagne on the table. Everyone looks exhausted and depressed. Anne-Marie has a black eye. Zissou is not pres

dialogues.speaker: ANNE-MARIE
dialogues.text: I believe it’s criminal that Steve allowed this to happen to us -- by which I mean illegal. We’re being lead on an illegal suicide mission by a selfish maniac.  94.

dialogues.speaker: KLAUS
dialogues.text: (pause) I hear what you’re saying, but I think you misjudge the guy.

dialogues.speaker: INT. HALLWAY. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Zissou comes down the corridor. Klaus is waiting outside dining room. Loud shouting and commotion comes from insid Klaus whispers urgently:

dialogues.speaker: KLAUS
dialogues.text: Steevsy, I think the crew might be ready to mutiny. Pause. Zissou cracks open the door to the dining room and looks inside. He says wearily:

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: Ah, man. What a drag.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. MAIN DECK. DAY
dialogues.text: The next morning. Zissou, Ned, Klaus, Pelé, and Ogata sta with their heads bowed and their hands clasped in front o them. They are gathered around the body of the dead pirat It is wrapped in a red and white gingham-checked tableclo The three-legged dog sits beside it. Ned is covered with bruises, stitches, and bandages. He leans on a cane. Vikr films the scene. Klaus unfolds a a bundle of little scraps of paper. He cl his throat and begins:

dialogues.speaker: KLAUS
dialogues.text: St. Paul said to the Corinthians --

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: (looking off) Holy shit. Son of a bitch. (to Vikram) Cut. Vikram keeps filming. An enormous, space-age, highly futuristic yacht made of plastic, glass, and titanium pul up dangerously close alongside the Belafonte and comes to full stop. Twenty-five men in white uniforms throw lines, jump down steps, run across catwalks, and watch with binoculars. Operation Hennessey is printed on the crew members’ caps and across the side of the ship. Hennessey stands at the prow in his lab coat and pink cashmere scarf with an elephant gun cocked over his shoul  95. His Japanese television crew is circled around him. He ye over a P.A. system:

dialogues.speaker: HENNESSEY
dialogues.text: This is Captain Hennessey! We’ve come in response to your distress signal! Remain calm and -- good God, is that you, Steven?

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: {to Ogata) Run downstairs and put a tarp over anything with Hennessey written on it. Ogata nods and goes inside. Klaus motions to the dead pir at their feet.

dialogues.speaker: KLAUS
dialogues.text: What about this guy?

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: (pause) Just throw him in.

dialogues.speaker: INT. HENNESSEY'S QUARTERS. DAY
dialogues.text: An immaculate, polished-teak sitting room. There are nume control panels with blinking displays and buttons. A silv nitrate print of the photograph of Lord Mandrake is frame the wall. Hennessey sits draped over a camel’s hair sofa a glass of white wine in his hand. Zissou is in a pink si armchair with fringe on it across from him. The three-legged dog growls at Zissou’s side. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: HENNESSEY
dialogues.text: Your engine blew up and all your fuel’s been stolen. Is that correct? ZISSoU Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: HENNESSEY
dialogues.text: Well, I certainly know how you feel. Some crooked fuckers just stripped my sea-lab, you know. Zissou hesitates. He mumbles:

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: Probably the same dudes.  96.

dialogues.speaker: HENNESSEY
dialogues.text: (shrugs) I can tow you as far as Port-au-Patois. T’1l need your signature on this invoice first. It accounts for the expenses of the rescue operation, as well my time and that of my crew. Hennessey hands Zissou a bill. Zissou examines it.

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: This is more than the budget of my whole project.

dialogues.speaker: HENNESSEY
dialogues.text: It’s an estimate. Zissou sighs. He re-reads the invoice. The dog scratches the sides of Zissou’s armchair.

dialogues.speaker: HENNESSEY
dialogues.text: What’s your dog’s name?

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: (pause) Cody. Hennessey nods. He rolls up a newspaper. He goes over to dog, still scratching at the chair, and swats it hard acr the body. The dog yelps and recoils.

dialogues.speaker: HENNESSEY
dialogues.text: Be still, Cody. Zissou looks startled. He frowns and pets the dog. Hennes sits back down on the sofa. Zissou holds up the invoice.

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: I have to run this by my bond company stooge.

dialogues.speaker: HENNESSEY
dialogues.text: He's been kidnapped.

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: (hesitates) That’s true. I got to rescue him first.

dialogues.speaker: HENNESSEY
dialogues.text: Sign it now, or I’m leaving you out here. Pause. Zissou signs the bill. Hennessey takes it. Somethi catches Zissou’s eye in an aquarium across the room. He

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: frowns. He points at it and looks to Hennessey. Hennessey nods knowingly. Zissou gets up and walks over to the aquarium. Hennessey turns off the overhead lights and joins him. Plastic tube and wires stick out of the water, and a digital thermomet hangs on the edge of the tank, connected to a computer. T is a navy blue squid-like creature the size of a football swimming figure-eight patterns and turning itself inside and back again. It has one green eye. Hennessey says quietly:

dialogues.speaker: HENNESSEY
dialogues.text: Hydronicus Inverticus.

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: (awestruck} A rat-tail envelope fish. This is the first one I’ve ever seen. (looking to Hennessey) How much you want for him?

dialogues.speaker: HENNESSEY
dialogues.text: Not for sale, I’m afraid. Zissou taps on the glass and stares at the creature. It breathes audibly.

dialogues.speaker: HENNESSEY
dialogues.text: All right. Let him go back to sleep.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Hennessey holding the door open for Zissou and the three- legged dog to walk across a gangplank back to the Belafon Hennessey has his arm around Zissou’s shoulder. He wears neat leather supply belt around his waist. Zissou notices and says distractedly:

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: Where’d you get that little fanny pack from?

dialogues.speaker: HENNESSEY
dialogues.text: (suspiciously) What? My supply belt? It’s by Hartwell and Kent. Why?

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: (shrugs) Not a bad crew gift.  98.

dialogues.speaker: HENNESSEY
dialogues.text: {suddenly) Oh, I dined with Eleanor last weekend, by the way. She’s summering at my villa in West Port-au-Patois, don’t you know. Say, how's Team Zissou holding up without her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A line being drawn on a wooden floor with a piece of chal

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Zissou on the deck of the Belafonte. His arms are folded front of his chest. His crew stands across from him. The three-legged dog sits beside him, growling.

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: The first thing that goes through a captain’s head when he hears there’s low morale going around is, What’d I do? Is it all my fault? Well, he’s probably right. Most of us have been together a long time, and there’s others who were here before that. Do you guys not like me anymore? I mean, what am I supposed to do? I don’t know. (pause) Look, if you’re not against me, don’t cross this line. If yes, do. OK? I love you all. Klaus immediately steps across the line. He looks to Ziss Zissou looks pained and stunned. He can barely manage to

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: Are you -- are you sure?

dialogues.speaker: KLAUS
dialogues.text: (confidently) Yes, I am. ZIssou I don’t understand. Why?

dialogues.speaker: KLAUS
dialogues.text: (confused) What do you mean? Wait a second. What are we doing? I thought you said cross the line if --

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: Cross the line if you want to quit.  99. Klaus quickly goes back to the other side.

dialogues.speaker: KLAUS
dialogues.text: Do it again. I misunderstood. The interns whisper and murmur with each other. They all cross the line. So does Anne-Marie. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: INT. RADIO ROOM. DAY
dialogues.text: A tiny cabin with telephone books from numerous exotic ci stacked on shelves and hundreds of telephone numbers scribbled on the walls. Jane sits alone at a little desk talking on the wireless. She says into the microphone:

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Hi, Ross. You’re probably at lunch, which is why I’m calling now. I got your corrections on the proofs. They’re fine, but -- I’m not coming back. It's over. Please, don’t try to contact me, OK? You'll hear from us sometime. {pause) We got attacked by pirates. I feel like life is -- well, you get the idea. Anyway, take care of yourself. Jane. INT. NED’S CABIN. DAY Ned and Jane sit side by side on his bunk holding hands. There is a paper sack on a chair next to the bed. Ned doe not look at Jane. Jane sounds distraught:

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: I'll probably just stay with my weirdo sister until I get things figured out. You understand, right? Ned nods. He says quietly:

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: Yes, that sounds like a good decision. Will you write to me?

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Of course. Give me the address. Ned reaches into the paper sack and takes out a stack of envelopes.
Well, actually, I went ahead and stamped and self-addressed fifty or so envelopes to make it easier for you. Ned hands Jane the envelopes. Jane looks touched.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Thanks. I’1l use them.

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: Each one has three blank pages in it, and here’s a pen. Ned gives Jane a blue and white ballpoint pen with four different colors that click from the tip. Pause.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Maybe I’m going to write you a letter right now.

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: (pleased) OK. Jane laughs. She kisses Ned on the cheek and then the lip

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: I bet I’m going to really miss you, Ned.

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: I’m going to miss you, too. In fact, feel like -- (with a lump in his throat) I don’t know. I feel like my heart’s getting broken. I guess I’m over- reacting. Jane hesitates. She looks suddenly lost.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Is that really true? Ned nods sadly.

dialogues.speaker: INT. HALLWAY. DAY
dialogues.text: Jane comes down the corridor toward her cabin.

dialogues.speaker: I
dialogues.text: She has tears in her eyes. She opens her door and starts to go inside. Zissou yells from the stairwell at the end of the hallway  101.

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: That was all off the record, cubbie! That whole deal. Actually, I’m surprised you didn’t cross the line yourself.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: What line?

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: (annoyed) The line I drew on the deck just now. Weren’t you up there?

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: (frustrated) You're kidding! That was one of the most dramatic things that’s ever happened on this boat. I just lost all my best interns. I thought you were supposed to be covering this story.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: You just said it was all off the record.

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: Yeah, but you didn’t know that.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Well, I was down here packing. Jane points to her packed suitcases lined up inside her cabin. Zissou locks disappointed. He walks wearily toward her.

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: So you are leaving. You're jumping ship on me.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: I’m going to scrap the article.

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: (hurt) You mean you’re not even going to write the cover story on me? Man, I just don’t have any stature any more.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, Steve. Everything just got too weird, that’s all.  102.

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: Yeah, but I gave you a goddamn show- stopper out there. We got -- (pause) Are you sleeping with Ned?

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (hesitates) That’s none of your business.

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: OK, but --

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: No, I’m not. Zissou nods. He sighs.

dialogues.speaker: Z1SSOU
dialogues.text: You're going to miss the jaguar shark or whatever it is, if it actually exists. (suddenly) Are you crying? What’s wrong, Jane? Jane shrugs. Zissou says gently:

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: You cry easily, don’t you? Zissou takes out a Team Zissou handkerchief and dries the tears on Jane’s cheeks.

dialogues.speaker: INT. RADIO ROOM. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Zissou sits wearily at the wireless. Drakoulias’ voice co over the line:

dialogues.speaker: DRAKOULIAS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Bloody hell. God save that poor little stooge. This never would’ve happened if Eleanor was with us.

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: (pause) Thanks, man.

dialogues.speaker: DRAKOULIAS, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: Your luck had damn well better change soon, laddie. Now I must away. I'11 send you a postcard from my travels.  103.

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: (concerned) What? Hold it. Where you going?

dialogues.speaker: DRAKOULIAS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (mysteriously) Abroad for a spell, my darling. It’s my passport status, you see. I’m X-9, at the moment. Legally, I’m a fugitive. Now I must bid you --

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: (upset) Wait a second! They stole my budget. The boat's broken. You’re ditching me up the creek. What am I supposed to do?

dialogues.speaker: DRAKOULIAS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (long pause) Well, I must say, nothing’s jumping to -- Phillip, any suggestions? (pause) No. He’s shaking his head. EXT. HENNESSEY’S YACHT. DAY A sailor in a crisp, white, Operation Hennessey uniform stands in the crow’s nest above the ship surrounded by computers and high-tech navigation equipment. He raises a pair of digital binoculars to his eyes. He lowers them suddenly. He reaches toward a button on a panel and start Say something -- but is interrupted by Klaus’ voice yelli

dialogues.speaker: KLAUS, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Port-au-Patois! Dead ahead! The sailor turns and looks quickly behind him. He holds u his digital binoculars.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: A digital binocular shot of Klaus standing alone on the l out tower of the Belafonte watching the horizon with Ziss boy scout binoculars. He picks up a bell and rings it violently. He shouts at the top of his lungs:

dialogues.speaker: KLAUS
dialogues.text: Land, ho!

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: The sailor lowering his binoculars. He frowns.  104.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. OCEAN. DAY
dialogues.text: Hennessey’s ship tows the Belafonte into the bay at Port- Patois.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. MAIN DECK. DAY
dialogues.text: The interns stand in a cluster in front of Zissou with al their duffel bags and knapsacks. Zissou says tensely:

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: No, I can’t give you full credit, but I'm not going to flunk you, either. You’re all going to get incompletes. The interns look furious. One of them mutters:

dialogues.speaker: INTERN
dialogues.text: This is bullshit. Zissou walks across the deck to the railing. He takes out passport and checks it. He puts on his red cap. Ned goes to him, smoking his pipe. Zissou examines the cuts and bruises on Ned's face.

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: They bashed you up pretty good, I guess. Ned nods. Pause. He says quietly:

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: Steevesy, I just wanted to say, in regards to the argument we had during the attack, because I still feel upset about it, and also in terms of the nick-names, well, I just wanted to say that -- what are we to each other? Am I -- zZIssou (sharply) Let’s just keep it in the moment, OK, Ned-o? Ned looks startled. He says reluctantly:

dialogues.speaker: OK.
dialogues.text: (suddenly snapping) Why? What does that mean? Zissou hesitates. He shakes his head and waves his hands. seems confused and agitated.  105.

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: Strike that. Look, why don’t you just decide what we are to each other, and whatever you come up with is fine with me, OK? Zissou climbs down a ladder onto the diving platform. Kla is pouring fuel from a gasoline can into the tank on a Zo motorboat. Zissou sighs.

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: Klaus, take down those interns mailing addresses and make sure they all get fanny packs. Hartwell and Kent.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. HARBOR. DAY
dialogues.text: Pelé drives Zissou to the marina in the Zodiak.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. PORT-AU-PATOIS. DAY
dialogues.text: A deeply impoverished tropical island. There are beggars children and soldiers with machine-guns. Zissou and a sma Filipino driver race through a shanty-town in a taxi with Port-au-Patois flags on the corners of the hood.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. VILLA. DAY
dialogues.text: A large house on the shore with a woven bamboo and grass roof. There are gardens, palm trees, and a goldfish pond. collection of small chrome buildings, observation towers, a geodesic dome surround the main structure. Zissou’s tax waits in the road. Zissou knocks on the ornately carved f door. He watches some tiny black frogs leaping around on path doing little back-flips. Hennessey Villa is written the pavement beneath them in chrome mosaic tile. Eleanor opens the door. She is dressed in a black leotard pink tights with a cream-colored scarf wrapped around her waist. Her hair is tied back into a knot, and loose stran stick to the sweat on her forehead. Classical music plays loudly from the next room.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Oh, shit. What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: Do you mind if I butter you up a little before I answer that question?

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Yes, I do. Tell me now.  106.

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: I need some money to get the boat out of hock and rescue my bond company stooge who got kidnapped. Could we ask your parents to loan it to me?

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: (pause) OK. Could I go ahead and butter you up, anyway? It took me two and half hours to get out here.

dialogues.speaker: INT. VILLA. DAY
dialogues.text: Zissou follows Eleanor through a hallway into a living ro with grass-mat floors, chaises-longues, and oil lamps. Th are photographs of Hennessey with various celebrities and dignitaries on the walls. The sun is setting on the ocean outside. Eleanor turns down the volume on the stereo. A tall Spanish man in a leotard waits in the next room stretching with one foot on a table. Zissou sees him and frowns. He points at the Spanish man.

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: Who’s that dude?

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Oh. That‘s my research assistant, Javier. Javier, te presento Steve. The Spanish man stands up and shakes Zissou’s hand. He an Eleanor exchange a few words in Spanish, and the Spanish goes outside. Zissou watches out the window as the Spanis man runs down the stairs peeling off his leotard. Zissou sighs. Zissou bends down to examine a twenty-year-old picture of Eleanor and Hennessey sharing a bellini in a gondola on t Grand Canal in Venice.

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: I’d be jealous about you staying at Allie’s place, except I’ve always thought he was kind of a closet queer. Eleanor and Zissou sit across from each other in two wick settees. There is a table in between them covered with Eleanor’s notes, charts, diagrams, and pictures of differ  107. species of penguin. There is also a manuscript entitled Classic Penguins by Eleanor Zissou. Eleanor takes out a brown cigarette, puts it in her mouth and lights it.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: How’s your father-son relationship coming along?

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: The sub-plot? Oh, you mean in real life. Yeah, I think I’ve become something of a father-figure to Ned. Or, at the very least, he’s my half~son.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: (hesitates) Half-son?

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
dialogues.text: Well, nobody has a lock on any of this, so I’m not sure how it all times out. I mean, I want him to think of me like a father, but the fact that there’s an outside chance he really could be my actual biological son makes it -- (struggling) -- very difficult for me. Eleanor nods. A yellow and green lizard darts onto the ar Zissou's settee. He lets it crawl onto his hand. The liza looks at him and yawns. Zissou sighs.

dialogues.speaker: ZISSOU
